tossups.answer: AAVE [or African American Vernacular English; accept Black Vernacular or Black English Vernacular or BEV or Black Vernacular English or BVE; prompt on “American English”; accept ebonics until read] <CK, Social Science> Bonuses

answers: Saint Cecilia [accept Ode to St. Cecilia or Ode for St. Cecilia’s Day] <AE, Classical Music>
parts: Name this opera, often considered the earliest surviving English opera, composed by John Blow.
John Blow taught this English composer whose opera Dido and Aeneas contains the aria “When I am laid in earth.”

Both Purcell and Blow composed odes to this patron saint of Music. Purcell’s Te Deum, which was composed for this saint’s feast day, was the first English-language Te Deum with orchestral accompaniment.

answers: Nazi Germany [or Third Reich] <CK, Other Arts>
parts: Name this bizarre opera by György Ligeti (“JURJ LIG-uh-tee”) in which Nekrotzar destroys Breughelland.

An extensively revised version of Le Grand Macabre was premiered at this festival in 1997. A staging of Hugo von Hofmannsthal’s Everyman is the centerpiece of this festival held annually in Mozart’s hometown.
In Le Grand Macabre, Ligeti satirizes this regime’s secret police as the “Gepopo.” This regime opened their Nuremberg Rallies with the overture from Wagner’s opera Rienzi (“ree-ENT-see”).

answers: four [or 4; accept Fourth Symphony or “The Four Temperaments”] <VS, Classical Music>
parts: Name these instruments, two of which “duel” on opposing sides of the stage by playing tritones before a “glorioso” coda in a certain symphony.
That timpani duel occurs in this Danish composer’s “Inextinguishable” Symphony. He wrote the operas Maskarade and Saul og David.
Nielsen’s “Inextinguishable” Symphony is of this number, and Nielsen’s Second Symphony is named for this number of “temperaments.” This is the typical number of movements in a symphony.
